description: Up to 40 meteors/hour. Best viewing after midnight under dark skies.
Best evening view of Venus, 47.2° from the Sun.
Known as the Wolf Moon. Fully illuminated at 22:28 UTC.
Best time to observe Mars all night long.
Dark skies ideal for deep-sky viewing. Occurs at 12:37 UTC.
Known as the Snow Moon. Fully illuminated at 13:55 UTC.
Best time to observe faint celestial objects. Occurs at 00:46 UTC.
Evening sky view. 18.2° from the Sun.
Known as the Worm Moon. Fully illuminated at 06:56 UTC.
Visible across the Americas. Moon may appear red.
Equal day and night. First day of spring in the Northern Hemisphere.
Best for stargazing. Occurs at 11:00 UTC.
Visible in Greenland, Europe, Russia. 93% coverage in Canada.
Known as the Pink Moon. Fully illuminated at 00:24 UTC.
Visible in morning sky, 27.4° from the Sun.
20 meteors/hour. Best after midnight with little moonlight.
Best for deep sky viewing. Occurs at 19:32 UTC.
Debris from Halley's Comet. Best viewing after midnight.
Known as the Flower Moon. Fully illuminated at 16:57 UTC.
Good for stargazing. Occurs at 03:04 UTC.
Morning view. 45.9° from the Sun.
Known as the Strawberry Moon. Fully illuminated at 07:45 UTC.
Start of summer in the Northern Hemisphere. Sun at Tropic of Cancer.
Great for viewing galaxies and nebulae. Occurs at 10:33 UTC.
Best evening view. 25.9° from the Sun.
Known as the Buck Moon. Fully illuminated at 20:38 UTC.
Dark skies for stargazing. Occurs at 19:13 UTC.
20 meteors/hour. Best after midnight under dark skies.
Known as the Sturgeon Moon. Fully illuminated at 07:56 UTC.
Up to 60 meteors/hour. Best after midnight.
Best morning view. 18.6° from the Sun.
Great night for observing faint deep-sky objects.
Known as the Harvest Moon. Fully illuminated at 18:10 UTC.
Visible in Asia, Australia, and parts of Europe and Africa.
Ideal for observing galaxies. Occurs at 19:55 UTC.
Visible in New Zealand with 76% coverage.
Best night to view Saturn and its rings.
Equal day and night. Start of autumn in the Northern Hemisphere.
Best time to observe Neptune all night long.
Known as the Hunters Moon. Closest approach to Earth.
Minor shower. Low rate (~10/hr), best early evening.
Moon not visible. Great night for stargazing.
20 meteors/hour from Halley's Comet. Best after midnight.
Best evening view. 23.9° from the Sun.
Bright fireballs. Low rate (~5–10/hr). Best after midnight.
Known as the Beaver Moon. Closest approach to Earth.
15 meteors/hour. Best after midnight.
Dark skies. Occurs at 06:49 UTC.
Best time to view Uranus all night.
Known as the Cold Moon. Closest approach to Earth.
Best morning view. 20.7° from the Sun.
Up to 120 meteors/hour. Best after midnight.
Moon not visible. Best time for observing faint objects.
First day of winter in Northern Hemisphere.
Minor shower. 5–10 meteors/hour. Best after midnight.
